page.title: 07MINING HISTORY
page.content: Across the S.W. corner of grid.ref. 550140 runs the course of a mineral railway which linked Welch Whittle Colliery(previously known as Darlington's Pit) to the main line at Clancutt (Grid Ref.563150).Timothy Hackworth's locomotive "Sans Pareil", which took part in the Rainhill Trials (1829),finished its working life on the mineral railways in Coppull.Mining has in the past,played an important part in the local economy.Since 1722, 18 pits sunk in vicinity of Coppull.Last to close was Chisnall Hall Mine in 1966. On 22nd. May 1852, a roof fall at this colliery claimed 33 lives. As a by-product of mining,the clay soils gave rise to brick manufacture. This industry declined following closure of the mines.However the local brick is still much in evidence in the housing of the district.
